name: UV-Induced Fluorescence Photography (Longwave)
summary: UV-induced fluorescence photography (longwave) is a non-invasive imaging technique that captures visible light emission (fluorescence, 400-700 nm) from materials excited by ultraviolet radiation in the UVA range (315-400 nm, typically 365 nm). When organic materials absorb UV photons, electrons transition to excited states and subsequently relax, emitting lower-energy photons in the visible spectrum—a phenomenon exploited to differentiate materials based on their molecular structure and age-related chemical changes. The technique uses longwave UV sources (365 nm peak, 'black lights', Wood's lamps) to illuminate objects while blocking reflected UV with camera-mounted filters, capturing only fluorescent emission. Different materials exhibit characteristic fluorescence colors: aged varnishes glow yellow-green (oxidized terpenes, aged natural resins), proteins fluoresce blue-white (collagen in parchment, silk), many modern synthetic materials appear dark/non-fluorescent (acrylic polymers, modern retouching media), and certain pigments show distinctive responses (zinc white bright blue-white, cadmium yellow-orange, lead white cream-yellow). Heritage applications include: retouching detection (modern conservation materials typically non-fluorescent vs. aged original fluorescent), varnish assessment (distribution, degradation, thickness variations visible via fluorescence intensity), material identification (organic vs. inorganic, natural vs. synthetic binders), authentication (modern materials, anachronistic restorations), and condition documentation (biological growth, stains, adhesive residues fluoresce distinctively). The technique is rapid (minutes per image), inexpensive ($500-$5,000 equipment), portable, and requires minimal training, making it a standard first-line examination tool in paintings conservation and manuscript studies worldwide.

fundamentalPhysics.principle: Fluorescence = absorption of high-energy photons (UV, short wavelength ~365 nm) → electronic excitation (electrons promoted from ground state S₀ to excited singlet state S₁) → rapid non-radiative relaxation (vibrational energy dissipation, ~ps timescale) → radiative decay to ground state emitting lower-energy photons (visible, longer wavelength 400-700 nm, Stokes shift). Emission occurs within nanoseconds (fluorescence lifetime ~1-10 ns for organic molecules typical heritage materials), distinguishing it from phosphorescence (forbidden transitions, μs-s timescale, afterglow). Fluorescence intensity and color depend on molecular structure: conjugated π-systems (aromatic rings in aged varnish, proteins, lignin) efficient absorbers/emitters; quantum yield Φ = photons emitted / photons absorbed (0.01-0.9 for organic fluorophores, material-specific). Aged materials often fluoresce more strongly than fresh (oxidation, cross-linking create chromophores: carbonyl groups, extended conjugation). Photography captures integrated emission across visible spectrum (RGB sensor), color determined by emission spectrum convolved with camera response.
fundamentalPhysics.physicalPhenomenon: Jablonski diagram: UV absorption (S₀ → S₁ transition, 365 nm ~3.4 eV) → vibrational relaxation (S₁ high vibrational levels → S₁ v=0, energy dissipated as heat) → fluorescent emission (S₁ v=0 → S₀ various vibrational levels, 400-700 nm ~1.8-3.1 eV). Stokes shift (emission red-shifted vs. absorption): energy lost to vibrational relaxation → emission wavelength > absorption wavelength (typically 50-150 nm shift; 365 nm excitation → 450-550 nm emission common aged organics). Quantum yield material-dependent: proteins (tyrosine, tryptophan residues) Φ ~0.1-0.3 (blue-white fluorescence), aged varnish (oxidized terpenes, abietic acid derivatives) Φ ~0.05-0.2 (yellow-green), modern acrylics Φ ~0.001-0.01 (weak/dark). Photobleaching: prolonged UV exposure → irreversible photochemical degradation (fluorophore destruction, Φ decreases over time; minimize exposure <30 min cumulative to prevent damage).

interactionDepth.description: UV penetration depth in materials determines fluorescence origin (surface vs. subsurface). UVA 365 nm: moderately penetrating (1-100 μm in opaque materials like paint, 100 μm - mm in translucent like varnish, parchment). Absorption coefficient material-dependent: dense pigmented paint (strong UV absorption, penetration <10 μm, surface fluorescence only), varnish layer (transparent to UV, penetration 50-500 μm, bulk fluorescence), parchment (collagen matrix, penetration 100 μm - 1 mm, subsurface + surface). Fluorescence emission escapes from shallower depth (self-absorption: emitted visible light also absorbed by material, especially if thick; effective emission depth ~10-100 μm typical, biased toward surface). Not depth-resolved (unlike OCT): integrates fluorescence from all depths within penetration range, weighted toward surface. Thick varnish (>100 μm) fluoresces more intensely than thin (<20 μm) due to more fluorophore volume, but relationship non-linear (self-absorption, scattering complicate).

materialSpecific.penetrationDepth: 50-500 μm (UV penetrates entire thickness if <500 μm, partial if thicker)
materialSpecific.visualizedFeatures: Bulk fluorescence (yellow-green, entire varnish layer glows), distribution (even vs. patchy application), degradation (darker fluorescence = more degraded)

materialSpecific.penetrationDepth: 5-50 μm (UV absorbed by pigments, surface fluorescence only)
materialSpecific.visualizedFeatures: Surface binder fluorescence (aged oil medium glows faintly yellow-cream), pigment-specific (zinc white bright, lead white cream, umber dark)
Bulk protein fluorescence (blue-white, entire thickness glows), ink (iron-gall dark absorbs UV, no fluorescence; carbon black also dark)
Lignin fluorescence (yellow, stronger in wood-pulp paper vs. rag), optical brighteners (modern paper, bright blue-white fluorescence), stains (foxing, water damage: orange-brown fluorescence)
Fiber fluorescence (silk blue-white protein, cotton/linen weak yellow cellulose), dyes (some fluoresce: madder orange-red, others dark), consolidants (applied adhesives fluoresce)

spatialResolution.lateral: Limited by camera resolution and optics, not UV fluorescence physics. Typical: 100-500 μm/pixel (standard photography setup, 1-5 m camera-to-object distance, 20-50 MP sensor). Can be improved: macro UVF (10-50 μm/pixel using macro lenses, close distance; see #4 macro + UV combination). No fundamental fluorescence-limited resolution (emission diffuse, scatters in material, but camera optics determine image sharpness).
spatialResolution.depth: Not depth-resolved. Integrates fluorescence over penetration depth (10-500 μm depending on material). Cannot distinguish 'fluorescence from 20 μm vs. 200 μm depth' (unlike OCT, confocal fluorescence microscopy). Entire UV-penetrated volume contributes to image.
limitingFactors: Camera resolution (sensor MP, lens quality; standard DSLR 20-50 MP → 100-500 μm/pixel @ 1-5 m distance)
Lighting uniformity (uneven UV → uneven fluorescence; shadows, hotspots reduce clarity)
Focus (fluorescence emission diffuse, but camera must focus on object surface for sharp image; shallow DOF at close range)
Noise (low fluorescence intensity → long exposure or high ISO → noise; reduces effective resolution, detail visibility)

sensitivity.description: Detects fluorescent materials at μg-mg levels (thin layers, trace residues visible if quantum yield adequate). Fluorescence intensity proportional to concentration × quantum yield × UV intensity: I_F ∝ Φ × c × I_UV (for optically thin samples). Minimum detectable: aged varnish ~5-10 μm thickness visible (fluorescence intensity ~10-100× above camera noise floor), animal glue residues ~1-5 μm (strong fluorescence, Φ ~0.1-0.3), modern acrylic retouching ~10-50 μm (weak fluorescence, Φ ~0.001-0.01, requires thicker layer for detection). Dynamic range: camera sensor 12-15 EV (4000-32000:1) → distinguishes fluorescence intensity variations 100:1 easily (bright vs. dark regions), 1000:1 with HDR techniques. Compared to naked eye: photography more sensitive (long exposure 2-30 s integrates weak fluorescence, eye ~30 ms integration → camera 100-1000× more sensitive). Spectroscopy more sensitive (dedicated fluorometers detect ppm-ppb fluorophores, but point-by-point slow; UV photography sacrifices chemical specificity for spatial coverage, speed).

source.type: Longwave ultraviolet (UVA) lamps: (1) Mercury vapor tubes (Wood's lamps: Hg emission peaks 365 nm + 405 nm, filtered to block visible), (2) UV-LEDs (365 nm ±10 nm, solid-state, compact), (3) UV flash (xenon flash tube + UVA filter, high-intensity pulsed).
source.specifications: **UVA wavelength:** 315-400 nm (defined range), typically 365 nm peak (convenient: strong Hg line, efficient excitation for most organics, minimal short-wave UV damage vs. UVB/UVC). **Intensity:** 1-100 W/m² @ 50 cm distance (handheld lamps 4-40W electrical, 0.5-5 W UV output; studio systems 100-400W, 10-50 W UV). **Spectrum:** Narrowband (365 ±10 nm LED, or 365+405 nm Hg filtered) vs. broadband (300-400 nm UVA range, less selective). **Filter:** Blocks visible light (Wood's glass, UV-pass filter: transmits 315-400 nm UV, blocks >420 nm visible; ensures lamp emits only UV, camera sees only fluorescence not reflected UV).
source.powerRange: Handheld lamps: 4-40W electrical (0.5-5W UV output, 1-10 W/m² @ 50 cm). Studio lamps: 100-400W electrical (10-50W UV, 10-100 W/m² @ 1 m). UV flash: 200-1000 W·s stored energy (high peak UV intensity, brief pulse ~1 ms).

detector.type: Digital camera: DSLR, mirrorless, or medium-format. Standard RGB sensor (Bayer array, typical) or monochrome (specialized, higher sensitivity, no color info). Modified or unmodified (stock cameras work; UV-modified cameras remove IR-cut filter for higher UV transmission, but UVF uses visible fluorescence so modification not essential).
detector.spectralRange: Captures visible fluorescence emission: 400-700 nm (standard RGB sensor response). Excitation blocked by camera filter (UV-absorbing, Schott GG400, or yellow filter: transmits visible 420-700 nm, blocks UV <400 nm → camera sees only fluorescence, not reflected UV).
detector.efficiency: Quantum efficiency: 40-60% peak (modern CMOS sensors, 500-600 nm). Fluorescence emission typically 450-600 nm (blue-yellow-green for most heritage materials) → good sensor match. UV-modified cameras (IR-cut filter removed): slight sensitivity improvement in blue 400-450 nm (5-10% gain), but stock cameras adequate (fluorescence emission mostly >420 nm, standard sensors efficient there).
detector.resolution: Standard camera sensors: 20-60 MP (5000×3300 to 9500×6300 pixels). Spatial resolution limited by camera-to-object distance, lens (not fluorescence); see spatial resolution section. Higher MP preferred (more detail, but diminishing returns >30-40 MP for typical object sizes, distances).

components: **UV source (lamps or flash):** 2-4 UV lamps (handheld 4-40W, or studio-mounted 100-400W, positioned 30-90° to surface for even coverage), or UV flash units (substitute for visible flash, same mounts/controls). Wood's lamps common (Spectroline, UVP, Labino: 4-8W handheld tubes, 365 nm peak, filtered). LED UV panels (cheap: $50-200, 20-100W, 365 nm; Amazon, Ali-Express; adequate for small objects, lower intensity vs. professional).

**Camera body:** DSLR or mirrorless (manual control essential: exposure, focus, ISO). Full-frame preferred (larger sensor → better low-light performance, lower noise; UVF often dim, long exposures). Examples: Nikon D850, Canon 5D IV, Sony A7R IV.

**Lens:** Standard photography lens (50 mm, 24-70 mm zoom, typical). No special UV optics required (fluorescence emission visible wavelengths, normal glass transparent). Macro lens if close-up UVF (see #4 macro + UVF combination).

**Camera filter (UV-blocking, yellow):** Critical component. Blocks reflected/scattered UV, transmits visible fluorescence. Options: (1) Schott GG400 or GG420 (glass UV-cut filter, transmits >400 or >420 nm, blocks <400 nm; 2-3 mm thick, screw-mount or gel holder, $50-200). (2) Yellow filter (Wratten #8, #12, Lee #101 Yellow; transmits >500 nm, blocks UV+blue; enhances contrast if fluorescence yellow-green, $10-50). (3) Clear UV filter + yellow gel (combination: UV filter blocks UV, yellow further enhances; $20-100 total). Mount: screw onto lens (52-82 mm thread), or gel holder (sheet filters, flexible).
**Tripod:** Stable support (long exposures 2-30 s typical UVF; handhold impossible, tripod essential). Remote shutter (cable, wireless, or 2 s timer: avoid vibration).

**Dark environment:** Blackout curtains, dark room (suppress ambient visible light → camera sees only fluorescence, not reflected room light). Or shoot in darkened gallery/storage (after-hours, lights off). Ambient light contaminates: room light + fluorescence captured → washes out fluorescence, reduces contrast. Dark room: fluorescence-only image, maximum contrast.

**Scale, color reference (optional):** Include in frame (same as normal photography; allows measurement, color comparison). Some fluorescence references available (uranium glass, fluorescent minerals: emit known colors, calibrate camera response; specialty, not routine).
opticalSystem.beamPath: UV lamp → object (absorbs UV, emits visible fluorescence) → camera filter (blocks UV, transmits visible) → lens → sensor (captures fluorescence image). Critical: UV must not reach sensor directly (would overexpose, damage; filter blocks it). Only fluorescence passes filter (Stokes-shifted, longer wavelength than excitation → filter transmits).
opticalSystem.focusing: Standard photography focusing (autofocus or manual). Focus on object surface (fluorescence emission from surface/near-surface, depth ~10-100 μm; camera focuses on surface for sharp image). Live view helpful (dim fluorescence visible on LCD, easier than viewfinder; magnify for precise focus).

criticalComponents: UV-blocking filter on camera (Schott GG400, yellow filter; without it, reflected UV reaches sensor → overexposed white image, no fluorescence visible; ESSENTIAL)
Filtered UV source (Wood's lamp, UV-LED; emits UV only, minimal visible; cheap unfiltered 'black lights' emit visible purple → contaminates image, use proper Wood's lamps)
Dark environment (ambient light <10 lux; otherwise room light + fluorescence mixes, reduces contrast, washes out weak fluorescence)
Stable camera (tripod + remote shutter; long exposures, vibration = blur)
instrumentation.typicalConfiguration: **Museum conservation lab setup:** Camera: Nikon D850 (45 MP full-frame, excellent low-light ISO 64-25600, 14.8 EV dynamic range), 50 mm f/1.8 lens (fast aperture for dim fluorescence, or f/4-f/8 if adequate light, more DOF). Tripod-mounted 2-5 m from object (painting, manuscript, textile on easel or table). Camera filter: Schott GG400 UV-blocking filter (52 mm screw-mount, transmits >400 nm, blocks UV <400 nm; $80-150). Lighting: 2× Spectroline BIB-150P (150W longwave UV lamps, 365 nm, filtered, $300-600 each), mounted on light stands, positioned 45° left/right of object (1 m distance, even UV coverage, no harsh shadows). Settings: Manual mode, ISO 800-3200 (balance noise vs. light; fluorescence often dim, need higher ISO than normal photography), aperture f/5.6-f/8 (adequate DOF for flat paintings ±5 cm, sufficient light), shutter 2-15 s (long exposure integrates weak fluorescence, tripod stable), RAW capture. White balance: custom or fixed (3200K tungsten approximates fluorescence emission yellow-green, but not critical, adjust post). Environment: darkened room (lights off, blackout curtains, ambient <5 lux; only UV lamps on, camera sees only fluorescence). **Portable field setup:** Camera: Canon 5D IV or similar, 24-70 mm lens. Handheld UV lamps: 2× Labino Midlight (8W UV-LED handheld, 365 nm, battery-powered, $200-400 each), held by assistant or mounted on lightweight stands. Camera filter: Tiffen UV-Haze or Hoya UV + Wratten #12 yellow gel (combined: block UV, enhance contrast; $30-80 total). Tripod: travel tripod (Manfrotto BeFree, 2 kg, supports 8 kg). Settings: similar to studio (ISO 1600-6400 if lamps lower power, shutter 5-30 s, f/4-f/5.6). Field constraints: ambient light control harder (shoot dusk/night, or improvised blackout tent over object + camera; or accept ambient, process to subtract background). **Budget DIY setup ($200-500 total):** Camera: any DSLR with manual mode (used Canon Rebel, Nikon D3xxx series, $200-400). Lens: kit lens 18-55 mm. UV lamps: 2× cheap UV-LED black lights (Amazon $25-50 each, 20-50W, 365 nm; adequate for small objects <50 cm, lower intensity vs. professional). Camera filter: Hoya HMC UV(0) filter ($20-40) + yellow gel sheet (Lee #101, $5-15). Tripod: budget ($30-100). Total: $300-650. Compromises: lower UV intensity (longer exposures 15-60 s, or higher ISO 3200-12800, more noise), cheaper filters (more UV leakage, slight purple cast), but functional for routine retouching detection, varnish assessment (adequate for 80% heritage applications).

facilityRequirements.space: Small studio, conservation lab, or gallery. 3×3 m minimum (object, camera 2-5 m away, lights on stands, maneuvering space). Darkening capability (blackout curtains, or after-hours in museum gallery lights-off). No special construction (portable setup, temporary blackout acceptable).
utilities: Electrical: 110/240 VAC, 10-15 A (UV lamps 2×150W = 300W, or LED 2×50W = 100W; camera, computer if tethered).
No water, gas, exhaust (UV lamps emit ozone trace amounts, but negligible at UVA wavelengths vs. UVC; ventilation normal room adequate).
Darkening: blackout curtains, shades, or after-hours (suppress ambient visible light <10 lux for optimal contrast; or accept ambient, longer exposures, post-processing to subtract background).
environmental: Temperature: comfortable 18-25°C (equipment, operator; no special cooling needed, UV lamps warm slightly <50°C surface, safe for objects if exposure brief <30 min).
Humidity: standard lab 30-60% RH (no special requirements; objects, electronics tolerate normal range).

UV safety: UVA (365 nm) low acute hazard (vs. UVB/UVC), but prolonged skin/eye exposure → erythema, photodamage. Safety measures: UV-blocking glasses (amber, block <400 nm; protect operator eyes if working near lamps hours), minimize direct gaze at lamps, limit object exposure <30 min cumulative (prevent photobleaching fluorophores, photochemical damage to organics).

commercialSystems.specifications: 150W mercury vapor lamp, 365 nm peak, filtered (Wood's glass: blocks visible, transmits UVA), ~20 W UV output @ 15 inches (38 cm). Bench-mount or handheld. Standard industrial/conservation UVF source.
6W longwave (365 nm) handheld lamp, 4×15 cm illumination area, battery or AC powered, filtered. Portable field use.
8W UV-LED, 365 nm ±5 nm, battery-powered (4 hr runtime), 15×20 cm spot @ 40 cm, lightweight (500 g). Conservation-oriented, Swedish manufacture.

Studio flash modified with UVA filters (UV-pass + visible-block), 200-1000 W·s. High-intensity pulsed UV for fast imaging (1/200 s sync speed vs. 2-30 s continuous). Specialty, expensive ($2,000-$5,000 per head).

samplePreparation.sampleSize: Entire objects imaged in situ. No size limit (UVF applicable to 1 cm micro-objects to 10 m murals; adjust UV lamp placement, camera distance). Typical: paintings 0.5-5 m², manuscripts 20×30 cm, textiles 1-10 m², sculptures variable.
samplePreparation.mountingProcedure: Position object as for normal photography (easel, wall, table). No special mounting. Ensure access for UV lamps (position lamps 30-90° to surface, 50 cm - 2 m distance depending on power, coverage needed). For large objects (murals): may require scaffolding, lifts to position lamps uniformly.
samplePreparation.surfacePreparation: None required typically. Clean surface optional (dust scatters UV, may reduce fluorescence signal slightly; soft brush or compressed air if conservation permits, but often unnecessary, dust fluorescence itself informative). No coating, wetting, contact (completely non-invasive).
samplePreparation.contaminationConcerns: Ambient light (room light contaminates fluorescence image → darken room, blackout curtains essential for clean images). Fingerprints, oils (on object: natural skin oils may fluoresce faintly blue-white, could confuse; on camera filter: block light, reduce transmission → clean filter with lens cloth before use). Ozone (UVA lamps emit trace ozone, especially mercury vapor; not hazardous at typical concentrations, exposure durations, but ventilate room if long sessions >1 hr continuous operation).

steps.title: Equipment Setup and Safety Preparation
steps.description: **Camera setup:** Mount camera on tripod, position 2-5 m from object (framing to include entire object or area of interest). Attach UV-blocking filter to lens (Schott GG400 or yellow filter; screw onto front element, verify secure). Set camera Manual mode (full control exposure, focus). **UV lamps:** Position 2-4 lamps around object (45° angles typical: front-left, front-right, and optionally back-left, back-right if large object; 0.5-2 m distance depending on lamp power, desired coverage). Angle lamps to illuminate object evenly (avoid shadows, hotspots; test by observing UV-induced fluorescence visually, adjust until even glow). Plug in lamps (AC power), or charge batteries (if battery lamps). Do NOT turn on yet (UV exposure minimized until ready to shoot). **Safety:** UV-blocking eyewear for operator (amber glasses, block <400 nm; optional but recommended if working near UV lamps for extended periods >30 min cumulative; UVA less hazardous than UVB/UVC but prolonged exposure → eye strain, potential lens damage over years). Warning signs (if public space: 'UV imaging in progress, do not enter' or similar; prevent accidental exposure, explain unusual lighting). **Environment:** Darken room (lights off, close curtains/shades, blackout if available; ambient light <10 lux ideal; measure with light meter or smartphone lux app). If complete darkening impossible (gallery, field): shoot during dusk/night, or accept ambient, plan to subtract in post-processing (less optimal but workable). **Test shot (optional):** Turn on UV lamps briefly (30 s), turn off room lights, observe object (naked eye: should see fluorescence glow, colors distinctive; camera live view: image appears on LCD, adjust framing). Turn off UV lamps (minimize object exposure until final capture).
steps.duration: 20-30 minutes (initial setup; subsequent sessions 5-10 min if equipment stored ready)
criticalParameters: UV-blocking filter on camera (ESSENTIAL; verify installed, secure, clean)
Room darkened (ambient <10 lux; blackout curtains, lights off)
UV lamps positioned for even coverage (test, observe fluorescence, adjust angles, distances)
Safety eyewear (if prolonged work near UV; UVA low risk but prudent precaution)

steps.title: Normal Visible Light Photography (Baseline Comparison)
steps.description: Before UVF: capture standard visible light photograph (same framing, camera position, lighting setup but with normal lights instead of UV). Purpose: baseline for comparison (normal appearance vs. fluorescence), documentation (show object in natural state), alignment reference (overlay normal + UVF in post-processing, register features). Procedure: UV lamps OFF, room lights ON (or daylight, or studio lights: normal illumination). Camera filter (UV-blocking) can remain (transmits visible, so normal photo unaffected) or remove (slightly more light, but minimal difference). Camera settings: Manual mode, ISO 100-400, aperture f/8-f/11 (adequate DOF), shutter 1/60-1/250 s (normal exposure for ambient/studio lights), RAW capture. White balance: custom (gray card, or auto). Capture baseline image. Review (histogram, focus, framing). Note settings (will differ from UVF settings: normal photo shorter exposure, lower ISO; UVF longer exposure, higher ISO due to dim fluorescence).
criticalParameters: Same framing as UVF (allows pixel-aligned comparison; do not move camera/tripod between normal and UVF shots)
Good exposure (histogram centered, no clipping; baseline must be well-documented for comparison)
RAW format (preserve data, flexibility in post-processing)

steps.title: UV Fluorescence Imaging (Primary Capture)
steps.description: **Pre-exposure setup:** Room lights OFF (complete darkness or <5 lux ambient). UV lamps ON (wait 30-60 s for stabilization if mercury vapor lamps; LEDs instant, no warm-up). Camera: verify UV-blocking filter installed (check filter on lens, essential). Live view enabled (rear LCD or tethered to computer; observe fluorescence image in real-time, easier than viewfinder in dark room). **Exposure determination:** Metering challenging (camera meter may underexpose fluorescence, which is dim; manual adjustment recommended). Start with settings: ISO 1600-3200 (balance noise vs. light; fluorescence typically weak), aperture f/5.6-f/8 (sufficient DOF for flat objects ±5 cm, allow more light than f/11), shutter 5-15 s (initial guess; long exposure integrates weak fluorescence). Capture test shot (review histogram: should be centered or slightly right for ETTR - expose to the right, maximize signal, minimize noise; if too dark, increase shutter 15 → 30 s or ISO 3200 → 6400; if too bright, decrease shutter 15 → 5 s or ISO 3200 → 1600). Iterate (2-3 test shots typical until histogram optimal). **Focus:** Manual focus via live view (autofocus struggles in dim fluorescence; switch lens to manual, use live view 5-10× magnification, focus on object surface features: edges, texture; focus on fluorescence itself, which coincides with object surface). Verify sharpness (zoom 100% in live view, adjust focus until sharp; critical, refocus if blurred). **Final capture:** Settings finalized (ISO, aperture, shutter for correct exposure; focus sharp). Remote shutter release or 2 s timer (avoid vibration from button press, long exposure 5-30 s sensitive to shake). Trigger capture (camera exposes 5-30 s, red LED blinking; do not move camera, object, or lamps during exposure). Wait for completion (image saves to card, 2-5 s for RAW file). **Review immediately:** Display image on LCD (zoom 100%, check focus, exposure, fluorescence distribution). Histogram (verify no clipping highlights or crushed shadows; fluorescence dynamic range wide, bright areas: varnish, zinc white; dark areas: modern retouching, iron-gall ink; histogram should cover range without clipping extremes). If satisfactory: note settings, proceed to additional views (different angles, details, close-ups if needed). If issues (underexposed, blurred, uneven lighting): adjust, retake (better to spend extra time now than discover problems later when object unavailable). **Multiple exposures (optional):** If dynamic range exceeds camera (very bright fluorescence + very dark non-fluorescent areas): bracket exposure (e.g., 5 s, 15 s, 45 s), merge HDR in post-processing (extend effective dynamic range, capture both bright varnish and faint retouching fluorescence in single composite).
steps.duration: 10-20 minutes per view (including test shots, exposure iteration, final capture; faster if experienced, 5 min; slower if first time, 30 min)
criticalParameters: UV-blocking filter on camera (without it, image will be overexposed white from reflected UV; verify BEFORE exposing)
Exposure optimized (histogram centered or ETTR; if too dark, increase shutter/ISO; if too bright, decrease; fluorescence dim, easy to underexpose)
Focus sharp (manual focus via live view; autofocus unreliable in dim fluorescence)
Stable camera (tripod, remote shutter, no vibration during long exposure 5-30 s)
Minimal UV exposure to object (total cumulative <30 min; prolonged UV → photobleaching, photochemical damage; capture efficiently, turn off lamps between shots if multi-view session)

steps.title: Detail and Close-Up UVF (Optional)
steps.description: For high-resolution fluorescence imaging of specific areas (retouching details, varnish variations, inscription fluorescence): move camera closer or use macro lens (see #4 macro + UVF combination). Maintain UV lighting (may need to reposition lamps closer for even coverage of smaller FOV). Same procedure (darken room, UV on, camera filter, manual exposure, focus). Macro UVF challenges: (1) **Shallow DOF** (macro magnification → DOF 300-500 μm @ f/8, 1:1; may need focus stacking if 3D object, or stop down f/11-f/16, accept longer exposure or higher ISO). (2) **Lighting uniformity** (close distance, harder to light evenly; ring UV light ideal, or fiber-optic UV guides for oblique illumination). (3) **Intensity** (inverse-square law: close distance → much brighter UV → fluorescence stronger, but also easier to overexpose highlights; test exposure carefully, may need shorter shutter than wide-field UVF). Typical settings: ISO 800-1600 (lower than wide-field, closer distance stronger fluorescence), aperture f/8-f/11, shutter 2-10 s (less than wide-field 5-30 s). Captures: 5-20 detail areas typical (specific retouching spots, varnish boundaries, material transitions). Benefit: resolves fine features (10-50 μm/pixel macro UVF vs. 100-500 μm/pixel normal UVF; individual pigment grains fluorescence, fine cracks in varnish, thread-level textile fluorescence).
steps.duration: 30-60 minutes (5-20 details @ 3-5 min each including repositioning, exposure, capture)
criticalParameters: Lighting adjusted for close distance (reposition UV lamps, or use ring/fiber-optic UV for even macro illumination)
Focus critical (shallow DOF, must be precise; live view magnified focus essential)
Exposure compensation (closer = brighter UV = stronger fluorescence; test, avoid overexposure)

steps.title: Multi-Angle or Raking UVF (Advanced, Optional)
steps.description: Standard UVF: lamps at 45°, frontal illumination (even coverage, shows fluorescence distribution). Raking/oblique UVF: lamps at 5-20° grazing angle (enhances texture, surface relief visible via fluorescence shadows; combines fluorescence chemical info + topographic texture). Procedure: position 1-2 UV lamps low, nearly parallel to object surface (5-20° angle; creates shadows on surface irregularities, impasto, cracks). Lighting from one side (unidirectional, strong shadows), or both sides alternating (capture 2 images: left-raking, right-raking, compare). Camera setup same (darkened room, UV filter, long exposure). Result: fluorescence + texture shadows (varnish fluorescence shows distribution, shadows show impasto peaks/valleys, crack relief; combined information, richer than flat frontal UVF). Applications: brushstroke relief in varnished paintings (fluorescence shows varnish, shadows show impasto → correlate varnish application to original brushwork), textile weave (fluorescence shows dye, fiber type, shadows show weave structure, height differences). Limitation: shadows reduce fluorescence visibility in recessed areas (trade-off: gain texture, lose some fluorescence detail in shadows; often use frontal UVF for fluorescence mapping, raking UVF for texture documentation, not both in single image).
steps.duration: 15-30 minutes (additional captures with repositioned lamps; 2-4 raking angles typical if comprehensive)
criticalParameters: Lamp angle very low (5-20°; too high, no shadows; too low, uneven coverage, part of object shadowed)
Unidirectional or paired (single lamp one side, or two lamps alternating captures, compare left vs. right shadows)
Longer exposure may be needed (raking angle → less UV on some areas, fluorescence dimmer in shadows; compensate +1 to +2 EV shutter or ISO)

steps.title: Post-Capture Verification and Documentation
steps.description: **Immediate review:** After each UVF capture, verify on camera LCD or tethered computer screen (100% zoom, check sharpness, exposure, fluorescence distribution). Checklist: **Focus** (critical features sharp; if blurred, refocus, retake). **Exposure** (histogram good: fluorescence regions visible, not clipped or too dark). **Coverage** (entire object/area captured; no missing regions due to uneven lighting, shadows). **Fluorescence** (expected features visible: varnish glows, retouching dark/different, etc.; if unexpected, investigate: wrong filter, ambient light contamination, etc.). **Completeness** (all required views captured: overall, details, normal + UVF pairs; easier to check now than later when object/setup unavailable). **Turn off UV lamps** (minimize object exposure; if multi-view session, turn off between shots, not continuous operation; total cumulative exposure <30 min recommended, <60 min maximum to prevent photobleaching). **Metadata:** Note imaging parameters (log or voice memo: object ID, date/time, camera settings ISO/aperture/shutter, UV lamp type/power/distance, filter type, ambient conditions, operator name, purpose/notes). Camera EXIF (auto-records settings, but add IPTC keywords: 'UVF', 'longwave 365 nm', object ID, etc. for searchability). **Backup:** Copy RAW files from camera card to computer and backup drive (redundant storage; card failure, accidental deletion risk eliminated; immediate backup best practice).
criticalParameters: Critical review (100% zoom, verify quality; retake now if issues, not later)
Immediate backup (copy files off camera card; redundant storage prevents data loss)
Turn off UV lamps (minimize object exposure, prevent photodamage)
Metadata complete (settings, object ID, notes; aids interpretation, future replication, publication)

operatingParameters.notes: 365 nm standard (strong Hg emission line, efficient excitation organics, minimal damage vs. shorter UV). 375-380 nm also used (some LED sources), slightly less efficient excitation but safer (lower photon energy).

Higher intensity → brighter fluorescence, shorter exposure. Handheld lamps 1-10 W/m² @ 50 cm (adequate, longer exposure 15-60 s). Studio lamps 10-100 W/m² (faster, 2-15 s exposure). Diminishing returns >100 W/m² (fluorescence saturates, photobleaching risk).

Closer: brighter (inverse-square law: 2× distance → 1/4 intensity), but harder to light evenly (hotspot at center). Farther: even coverage, but dimmer (longer exposure or higher ISO). 0.5-1 m typical studio (balance coverage vs. intensity).

45° standard (even illumination, minimal shadows, good coverage). 30-60° frontal (standard UVF). 5-20° grazing (raking UVF, enhances texture). 90° perpendicular (if single lamp, used for small objects, even but single-direction).

Fluorescence dim → higher ISO than normal photography (typically ISO 100-400). ISO 800-1600 common (balance noise vs. light). 3200-6400 if weak fluorescence (modern materials, thin varnish). >6400 noisy (use for emergency/field, prefer longer exposure if tripod allows).

Wider than normal photography (f/8-f/16) to gather more dim fluorescence. f/5.6-f/8 typical (adequate DOF for flat objects ±5-10 cm, sufficient light). f/4 if very weak (shallow DOF, use for flat only). f/11 if strong fluorescence or need more DOF (3D objects, but longer exposure).

Long exposure integrates weak fluorescence. 5-15 s typical studio (adequate UV intensity, ISO 1600-3200). 15-60 s field/handheld UV lamps (lower intensity). >60 s rare (noise from sensor heating, diminishing returns; better increase ISO or add UV lamps). Bulb mode if >30 s (camera limit; use remote trigger, time manually or intervalometer).

GG400 (transmits >400 nm, blocks UV <400 nm; standard, passes blue fluorescence). GG420 (transmits >420 nm, blocks UV+deep blue; enhances contrast if fluorescence yellow-green, suppresses residual blue). Yellow filter (Wratten #8, #12: transmits >500 nm, enhances yellow-green fluorescence, suppresses blue; useful for aged varnish imaging where blue not important). Choice depends on application (GG400 general-purpose, yellow if want to emphasize yellow-green emission).

<10 lux ideal (fluorescence-only image, no ambient contamination, maximum contrast). 10-50 lux acceptable (slight ambient visible, can subtract in post, or longer exposure to dominate fluorescence). >50 lux problematic (ambient + fluorescence mixed, washes out weak fluorescence, reduces diagnostic value; darken room or shoot after-hours).

Minimize total UV exposure to prevent photodamage (photobleaching fluorophores, photochemical degradation organics). Single image 5-30 s safe. Multi-view session: 10-50 images × 10 s average = 100-500 s = 2-8 min total (safe). Turn off UV between shots (not continuous). Limit <30 min cumulative per object per day (conservative). If longer session needed (gigapixel UVF, 100+ tiles): monitor object, check for fading, accept risk, or use lower UV intensity (longer exposure per image but less total photon dose if fewer images).

standards: Fluorescence references (optional, specialized): Uranium glass (strong green fluorescence 520-530 nm, consistent; available antique glass, hobbyist sources), fluorescent minerals (willemite green, calcite red, etc.; geology suppliers), fluorescent plastic standards (some conservation labs: prepared standards of known materials, aged varnish samples, fluorescence documented; not widely available, custom).

Gray card / ColorChecker (for normal baseline image; less useful for UVF itself, as fluorescence colors material-specific, not standardized to gray/color patches; but include in frame if want to document scale, reference position).
calibration.frequency: Calibration minimal for qualitative UVF (standard conservation use: retouching detection, varnish assessment = qualitative, 'does it fluoresce yes/no, what color'; no calibration required). For semi-quantitative (compare fluorescence intensity between objects, sessions): include fluorescence reference (uranium glass piece in frame, always same position, same camera settings; reference intensity should be constant ±10%; if varies >20%, lamp intensity changed, camera response drifted, investigate). Per session: verify UV lamp output (turn on, observe fluorescence reference or test target; should glow consistently; if dim, lamp aging, replace tube/LED). Per setup: verify camera filter (inspect for scratches, smudges; clean, replace if damaged; UV leakage through damaged filter → overexposed image).
calibration.procedure: **Lamp verification (optional):** Before session, test UV lamp output (place fluorescence reference: uranium glass, willemite, or prepared varnish sample, under UV lamp @ 50 cm distance, darken room, observe glow brightness; compare to prior sessions, should be consistent; if 50% dimmer, lamp aging, replace). Quantitative (optional): use UV meter (Sper Scientific, General Tools: UV-A meter, $100-300; measures μW/cm² @ 365 nm; place at object position, record; compare to baseline, should be ±20%; if low, lamp aged or power supply issue). **Camera filter check:** Verify filter installed (visual inspection; if forgot, image will be all white from reflected UV, obvious error). Test for UV leakage (optional, paranoid check): point camera at UV lamp (lamp on, room dark, camera with filter), exposure settings for fluorescence (ISO 3200, f/5.6, 10 s); image should be black or very dark (minimal light from lamp visible emission leakage through Wood's glass filter, but mostly dark); if bright, filter damaged or wrong filter (e.g., UV-pass instead of UV-block, catastrophic error), replace immediately. **Exposure verification (qualitative):** Capture fluorescence reference (uranium glass, or known fluorescing object: aged varnish sample, white paper with optical brighteners), same settings as object (ISO, aperture, shutter); fluorescence should be visible, histogram centered or right (ETTR); if much darker than expected, camera settings wrong (ISO too low, shutter too short), or lamp dim, or filter wrong (e.g., ND filter accidentally on lens, blocks visible fluorescence). Troubleshoot, correct before imaging valuable object.

checkpoints: UV-blocking filter on camera (VERIFY before every session; if missing, image ruined, potential UV damage to sensor; visual check, confirm filter screwed on lens)

Exposure correct (histogram: fluorescence visible, not clipped highlights or crushed shadows; bright areas: varnish, zinc white; dark areas: modern materials, dark pigments; range should be represented without clipping extremes)
Focus sharp (zoom 100%, check critical features; fluorescence emission diffuse but image must be sharp; refocus if blurred)
Even UV illumination (no strong shadows, hotspots; check fluorescence distribution: should be even across object if uniform material; if uneven, adjust lamp positions, angles, distances)

Minimal ambient light contamination (if room not completely dark: check image, dark non-fluorescent areas should be black or very dark gray, not light gray from room light; if light, darken room more, or increase UV intensity to dominate)
No overexposure (highlights clipped = loss of detail in bright fluorescence; reduce exposure if histogram bunched right edge clipped; ETTR ideal: histogram right but not touching edge)

commonArtifacts.artifact: Overexposed white image (entire frame white, no detail)
commonArtifacts.cause: UV-blocking filter missing or wrong (UV-pass instead of UV-block; camera captures reflected UV, not fluorescence; UV much brighter than fluorescence, overexposes sensor instantly). Camera set to extreme overexposure (e.g., ISO 25600, f/2.8, 60 s; with UV filter, would be slight overexposure; without filter, catastrophic).
commonArtifacts.mitigation: ALWAYS verify UV-blocking filter installed (visual check before turning on UV lamps; make it habit, checklist item). If image white: STOP, check filter immediately (do not continue exposing object to UV, sensor to damage). Install correct filter (Schott GG400, yellow, etc.), retake. If filter was on, may be damaged (cracked, wrong glass; replace).

commonArtifacts.artifact: Underexposed dark image (fluorescence barely visible, noisy)
commonArtifacts.cause: Exposure too short (shutter 1-2 s inadequate for dim fluorescence; need 5-30 s typical). ISO too low (ISO 100-400 insufficient; increase to 1600-3200). Aperture too small (f/16-f/22 stops down too much; open to f/5.6-f/8). UV lamps too weak or too far (handheld 4-8W lamps @ 2 m distance may be inadequate; move closer or use more powerful lamps). Fluorescence intrinsically weak (object has minimal fluorescent materials: modern synthetics, dark pigments; acceptable, not an error, document as 'weak fluorescence, minimal emission').
commonArtifacts.mitigation: Increase exposure: longer shutter (5 → 15 → 30 s; watch histogram, should shift right), higher ISO (1600 → 3200 → 6400; balance noise), larger aperture (f/11 → f/8 → f/5.6; DOF trade-off). Increase UV intensity: move lamps closer (1 m → 50 cm: 4× brighter inverse-square), add more lamps (2 → 4: 2× brighter), upgrade lamps (4W → 40W: 10× brighter, or use UV flash). If object truly non-fluorescent (modern painting, all synthetic materials): accept, document ('UVF negative: minimal fluorescence observed, consistent with modern materials'), use other techniques (e.g., cross-polarization #3, multispectral imaging).

commonArtifacts.artifact: Color cast (entire image shifted purple, blue, yellow)
commonArtifacts.cause: Ambient light contamination (room light visible purple-blue from cheap unfiltered UV lamps visible emission leakage + actual fluorescence → mixed color). White balance incorrect (set to daylight 5500K but fluorescence emission yellow-green ~550 nm + camera response → shifts perception; not critical for qualitative UVF, but if color accuracy wanted, WB affects). Camera filter color (yellow filter enhances yellow-green fluorescence, suppresses blue; if used, image overall more yellow vs. GG400 clear filter which passes blue; acceptable, enhances contrast, but document filter type).
commonArtifacts.mitigation: Suppress ambient (darken room, blackout; if purple cast from UV lamps visible emission, use better-filtered lamps: Wood's lamps block visible, UV-LEDs better filtered vs. cheap black lights). Adjust white balance (shoot RAW, adjust WB in post-processing: if yellow-green fluorescence, set WB ~3200-4000K makes greens neutral, or accept as-is, qualitative; if color-critical: custom WB on fluorescence reference, or create profile, but rarely needed). Document filter type (if yellow filter used, note 'Wratten #12 yellow filter, enhances yellow-green fluorescence', so viewer knows not true-color rendering but enhanced for specific emission range).

commonArtifacts.cause: Uneven UV illumination (lamps too close, pointed at center; inverse-square + cosine falloff → center 5-10× brighter than edges). Single lamp (one light source, unidirectional; center bright, corners shadowed). Vignetting (lens + filter combo; wide-angle lens + thick filter stack → mechanical vignetting, dark corners; less common, usually <1 stop, but at long exposures becomes visible).
commonArtifacts.mitigation: Reposition lamps (move farther from object: 0.5 m → 1-2 m, flatter intensity profile; or add more lamps: 1 → 2-4, multi-angle coverage cancels shadows, evens field). Smaller aperture reduces vignetting (f/5.6 → f/8, but dims image, need longer exposure; or remove filter stack, single filter less vignetting). Post-processing: flatten field (Photoshop: duplicate layer, Gaussian blur high radius 500-1000 px, Subtract blend mode, adjust opacity → removes large-scale intensity variation, evens field; or use lens correction vignette slider +50-100). Prevention better (proper lamp placement, test shot, adjust before final capture).

commonArtifacts.cause: Camera moved during long exposure (vibration from shutter button, footsteps, building vibration, wind if outdoor; 5-30 s exposure, any movement → blur). Object moved (painting on easel shifted, textile sagged, live subject; rare for static heritage objects but possible if insecure mounting).
commonArtifacts.mitigation: Remote shutter (wired cable, wireless, or 2 s timer; do not touch camera during exposure). Stable tripod (heavy-duty, tighten all knobs, sandbag if needed). Isolate vibration (wait after touching camera, 2-5 s settle before exposure starts; shoot after-hours if building vibration from HVAC, traffic). Secure object (ensure painting/textile stable, will not shift; clamps, museum wax if needed). If unavoidable motion (outdoor, wind): shorter exposure (faster shutter, compensate with higher ISO or more UV lamps), accept slight blur, or shoot when calm.

commonArtifacts.artifact: Noise (grainy, speckled image, especially dark areas)
commonArtifacts.cause: High ISO (3200-12800; sensor noise increases, especially shadow regions). Long exposure (>30 s; sensor heats, thermal noise, hot pixels appear as bright specks). Underexposure then post-processing boost (dark capture, brightness increased +2-3 EV in post → amplifies noise buried in shadows).
commonArtifacts.mitigation: Optimize exposure (ETTR: expose to the right, maximize signal, minimize noise; histogram bunched right without clipping; even if slightly bright, reduces noise vs. underexposed then boosted). Lower ISO if possible (increase UV intensity: more/closer lamps, or longer exposure if stable; allows ISO 1600 vs. 6400, 2-4× less noise). In-camera noise reduction (enable Long Exposure NR, High ISO NR in camera menu; processes dark frame subtraction, reduces hot pixels, thermal noise; adds 5-30 s processing time after each shot but cleaner image). Post-processing (denoise software: Topaz DeNoise AI, DxO PureRAW, Lightroom Noise Reduction; luminance NR 30-50, detail 50, color NR 25-50; reduces graininess, preserves detail; but cannot recover lost signal, prevention better than cure). If noise unavoidable (weak fluorescence requires ISO 12800): accept, document ('high-noise image due to weak fluorescence, ISO 12800 necessary'), interpret carefully (noise may mimic features, zoom 100%, verify).

commonArtifacts.cause: Contamination (fingerprints on object: natural skin oils fluoresce faint blue-white; dust, mold, adhesive residues: may fluoresce distinctively). Object materials unexpected (assumed modern paint non-fluorescent, but artist used zinc white primer: fluoresces bright blue; surprised conservator). Optical brighteners (modern paper, textiles, conservation materials: added to 'whiten', fluoresce bright blue-white under UV; ubiquitous since 1950s, diagnostic of modern but can confuse if not anticipated).
commonArtifacts.mitigation: Clean object (soft brush, compressed air before UVF if conservation permits; removes dust, fingerprints that confuse fluorescence; but often contamination itself informative: mold growth fluoresces, diagnostic). Verify materials (cross-reference UVF with other techniques: XRF identifies zinc vs. lead white, Raman confirms modern vs. historical pigments; UVF alone can mislead if unexpected materials). Document unexpected fluorescence (note in report: 'bright blue fluorescence UVF, unexpected; XRF confirms zinc white primer beneath paint layers, artist's material choice, not restoration'; investigative approach, not assumptions).

troubleshooting.problem: No fluorescence visible (entire image dark, even areas expected to fluoresce)
troubleshooting.solution: Check UV lamps on (verify power, switches; lamps should emit faint purple glow visible in dark room if looking at them, though Wood's glass filters much of visible; or test with fluorescence reference: uranium glass should glow green; if not, lamps off or failed). Verify camera filter (is it UV-blocking GG400, or accidentally ND filter, polarizer, etc.? Remove, inspect, confirm correct filter, reinstall). Increase exposure (ISO 1600 → 6400, shutter 10 s → 60 s; if still dark, fluorescence may be genuinely weak or lamps inadequate). Test different object (photograph known fluorescent material: white paper with optical brighteners, tonic water with quinine, uranium glass; if these fluoresce, setup works, original object just non-fluorescent; if not, equipment issue, troubleshoot lamps, filter, camera settings).

troubleshooting.problem: Image overexposed, fluorescence details lost (bright areas clipped white)
troubleshooting.solution: Reduce exposure: shorter shutter (30 s → 10 s → 5 s), lower ISO (6400 → 3200 → 1600), smaller aperture (f/5.6 → f/8 → f/11; balance with DOF needs). Check histogram (highlights clipped? Reduce exposure until histogram right edge pulls away from clipping, peaks 1-2 stops left of edge). If bright areas very important (e.g., varnish fluorescence is diagnostic, must not clip): bracket exposure (e.g., 5 s, 15 s, 45 s), merge HDR in post (recover both bright varnish and dark retouching in single composite; Photoshop: Merge to HDR Pro, or Lightroom: Photo > HDR, align images, tone-map). Prevention: ETTR but don't clip (histogram bunched right, not touching edge; requires careful test shots, iteration).

troubleshooting.problem: Fluorescence color different than expected (e.g., varnish fluoresces blue instead of yellow-green)
troubleshooting.solution: Verify wavelength (is UV lamp truly 365 nm longwave, or shortwave 254 nm UVC accidentally? UVC excites different fluorophores, shifts colors; check lamp label, confirm longwave 365 nm). Check camera filter (yellow filter suppresses blue, enhances yellow-green; if expecting blue fluorescence from protein, don't use yellow filter, use GG400 clear instead; or remove filter, test). Material variation (varnish types differ: dammar yellow-green, shellac orange, mastic yellow; if unexpected color, may be different varnish than assumed, investigate with other techniques). Modern restoration (blue fluorescence may be zinc white overpaint, not varnish; interpret carefully, correlate with normal photo, other imaging). Document (note in report: 'unexpected blue fluorescence, hypothesis: zinc white restoration or atypical varnish, further analysis recommended XRF/Raman').

troubleshooting.problem: Fluorescence uneven, patchy (not corresponding to object features)
troubleshooting.solution: Check UV illumination (lamps positioned evenly? Shadows, hotspots? Adjust lamp angles, distances; add lamps for even coverage). Varnish genuinely patchy (old restoration campaigns: some areas cleaned, revarnished, others original; fluorescence reveals treatment history, not artifact). Surface contamination (mold, dirt, adhesive residues fluoresce patchily; if truly contamination, informative; document, correlate with visual inspection). Post-processing (if uneven lighting unavoidable: flatten field in Photoshop, see artifact mitigation above; or accept, note in report 'uneven UV illumination, fluorescence distribution qualitative').

troubleshooting.problem: Image blurry despite tripod, remote shutter
troubleshooting.solution: Check focus (refocus manually via live view; autofocus may have missed, especially in dim fluorescence). Verify camera stable (tighten tripod knobs, sandbag; some tripods have slight play even when 'tight', vibration over 10-30 s exposure accumulates). Increase shutter speed if possible (blur from residual vibration: 30 s → 10 s may help, compensate with ISO 3200 → 6400 or open aperture f/8 → f/5.6; trade-off noise vs. sharpness). Use electronic shutter if available (mirrorless cameras: silent, zero vibration; DSLR mirror slap even with lock-up may vibrate slightly; switch to electronic if camera supports, eliminates mechanical vibration). If persistent: lens issue (front element loose, internal elements shifted; test lens on normal photo, if sharp, problem elsewhere; if blurry there too, lens damaged, service needed).

fileFormats: RAW (CR2, CR3, NEF, ARW; camera-specific; uncompressed or lossless)
TIFF (converted from RAW; 16-bit RGB, Adobe RGB or ProPhoto RGB; archival master)
JPEG (processed; 8-bit sRGB; distribution, reports, web; not archival)
rawDataFormat.dataStructure: Single image: 20-60 MB RAW (depending on sensor resolution). UVF pair (normal + UVF): 2× file size. Session (normal + UVF for overall + 10 details): ~25-50 images, 1-3 GB total RAW.
rawDataFormat.typicalFileSize: Per image: 25-50 MB RAW, 100-150 MB TIFF 16-bit, 10-20 MB JPEG. Session: 1-5 GB (20-100 images typical documentation).

preprocessing.description: Open RAW files in converter (Lightroom, Capture One, Photoshop ACR). Adjust: white balance (fluorescence yellow-green typical, set WB ~3200-4000K for neutral greens, or 5500K daylight if want to preserve 'warm' fluorescence tone; not critical, qualitative UVF, but consistency helps comparison). Exposure (±0.5-1 EV if needed; histogram optimization, ETTR if captured). Lens corrections (vignetting: flatten if uneven UV illumination caused dark edges; or leave if informative, genuinely uneven varnish distribution). Convert to TIFF 16-bit (ProPhoto RGB if want wide gamut for post-processing, or Adobe RGB if suffices). Maintain metadata (EXIF: camera settings, critical for replication; IPTC: object ID, 'UV fluorescence 365 nm', filter type, notes).
preprocessing.software: Adobe Lightroom Classic, Capture One, Photoshop ACR

preprocessing.description: If slight camera movement between normal and UVF shots: load as layers in Photoshop (File → Scripts → Load Files into Stack), select both, Edit → Auto-Align Layers → Reposition (or Auto if rotation needed). Crop borders if alignment shifted (small empty edges, crop to common area). Result: pixel-aligned normal + UVF, can flicker between layers (toggle visibility), or blend (transparency, difference mode) to visualize fluorescence vs. normal appearance simultaneously.

Increase contrast (fluorescence often low-contrast: bright varnish, mid retouching, dark background; increase contrast via Curves: S-curve, or Clarity/Texture sliders in Lightroom +30-50; enhances fluorescence differences, makes retouching more obvious). False-color (optional, artistic/educational): map fluorescence to unnatural colors (e.g., blue fluorescence → red, yellow → green; exaggerates differences, but non-standard, confuses if not labeled clearly; typically not done for scientific documentation, only public outreach/exhibitions). Subtract background (if ambient light contamination: capture ambient-only image, same exposure settings, UV lamps off, room lights on at low level; subtract from UVF image digitally, removes ambient, isolates fluorescence; rarely needed if room properly darkened).
preprocessing.software: Lightroom (Curves, Clarity), Photoshop (Curves, Levels, Channel Mixer for false-color)

steps.title: Visual Comparison (Normal vs. UVF)
steps.description: Load normal and UVF images side-by-side (dual monitor ideal) or as layers (Photoshop, toggle visibility). Identify differences: (1) **Retouching detection:** Areas fluorescent in normal but dark in UVF = modern conservation materials (acrylic retouching paint, synthetic fills; weak fluorescence → dark). Areas fluoresce same or similar in normal + UVF = aged original (both fluoresce yellow-green from aged binder). Mark retouching (overlay layer, paint red/yellow transparent, annotate boundaries). (2) **Varnish assessment:** Uniform yellow-green fluorescence = even varnish distribution. Patchy fluorescence (bright + dark areas) = varnish removed in some regions, remains in others (past cleaning campaigns), or thick vs. thin application (restorer applied unevenly). No fluorescence over paint = varnish removed entirely, or never varnished. (3) **Material differentiation:** Bright blue-white fluorescence = proteins (parchment, silk, animal glue), zinc white pigment, optical brighteners (modern paper/textiles). Yellow-green = aged varnish (natural resins), aged oil medium, lignin (wood-pulp paper). Orange-red = shellac, some aged varnishes, certain organic dyes (madder). Dark/non-fluorescent = carbon black, iron-gall ink, most modern synthetic pigments, acrylics. (4) **Condition issues:** Bright spots (mold, bacteria fluoresce distinctively; greenish-yellow, localized). Stains (water damage, foxing on paper: orange-brown fluorescence from degradation products). Adhesive residues (past repairs: animal glue, PVA fluoresce; often blue-white or yellow). Document observations (note locations, colors, interpretations: 'retouching detected upper left 5×8 cm, dark in UVF, modern acrylic likely'; 'varnish fluoresces uniformly except cleaned strip lower right, no fluorescence there').

steps.title: Quantitative Fluorescence Analysis (Optional, Semi-Quantitative)
steps.description: Measure fluorescence intensity (if comparing areas, objects, or monitoring changes over time): **ROI intensity:** Select regions (Photoshop: rectangular marquee, or polygon for irregular areas; or ImageJ: ROI manager), measure mean pixel intensity (e.g., 'varnished area mean 185 ± 35 (8-bit), retouched area mean 62 ± 18'). Compare: varnished 3× brighter than retouched → confirms fluorescence difference, quantifies. **Intensity profiles:** Line tool (ImageJ: line across boundary varnish/retouching, Plot Profile → graph intensity along line; sharp drop at boundary = distinct materials). **Area quantification:** Threshold fluorescence image (select fluorescent regions: intensity >100 for example, convert to binary, Analyze Particles → total fluorescent area 240 cm² of 800 cm² painting = 30% varnished, 70% unvarnished/retouched). **Color analysis:** Extract fluorescence color (split RGB channels: ImageJ → Image → Color → Split Channels; measure R, G, B separately in ROI; e.g., aged varnish: R=120, G=180, B=80 → yellow-green; zinc white: R=200, G=210, B=230 → blue-white; quantifies color, can cluster similar materials). Statistics (export to spreadsheet: Excel, GraphPad; plot histograms, scatter plots; compare: object A vs. B fluorescence intensity, treatment before vs. after). **Caveats:** Fluorescence intensity depends on many factors (UV lamp intensity, camera settings, varnish thickness, degradation state, etc.); absolute values not meaningful, relative comparisons only (within same session, same settings). Semi-quantitative (order of magnitude, factor 2-10 differences reliable; ±10% precision difficult without extensive calibration).

steps.title: Retouching Mapping (Detailed Documentation)
steps.description: Systematic retouching identification: (1) **Grid search:** Divide object into grid (e.g., 10×10 cm squares), examine each in normal + UVF, note retouching (tedious but comprehensive; for major paintings pre-treatment). (2) **Mark boundaries:** Photoshop: new layer, paint over retouching areas (red transparent overlay, 50% opacity), outline boundaries precisely (zoom 100%, follow fluorescence edge). (3) **Classify retouching:** Modern vs. old restorations (modern dark UVF + non-fluorescent UV; old restorations may fluoresce if aged varnish over retouching, or if oil-based retouching media aged → fluoresces faintly; distinguish via intensity: old retouching dims vs. original, modern very dark). Extent (measure area: ImageJ select overlay, Analyze → Measure Area → e.g., retouching total 85 cm², 4.2% of painting surface). (4) **Documentation figure:** Export composite (normal + UVF side-by-side, retouching overlay on UVF, labels/arrows indicating retouched regions; Figure caption: 'UV fluorescence reveals modern retouching (red overlay) in face, hands, background; dark fluorescence indicates acrylic or synthetic media, contrasts with yellow-green fluorescent original varnish/paint'). (5) **Treatment planning:** Conservator uses map (decide: remove all modern retouching, or selective; fill losses, re-retouch with materials that age-match fluorescence, or accept mismatch; monitor: re-image UVF post-treatment, verify retouching removed/replaced as planned).

steps.title: Varnish Condition Assessment
steps.description: Fluorescence indicates varnish presence, degradation, distribution: **Presence:** Uniform yellow-green fluorescence over paint = varnished (natural resin varnish: dammar, mastic; aged, oxidized → fluoresces). No fluorescence = unvarnished, or varnish removed, or synthetic varnish (some modern synthetics weak fluorescence: Paraloid B-72, MS2A; appear dark or faint in UVF, but visual gloss confirms varnish present → UVF alone misleading, correlate with normal photo). **Degradation state:** Bright fluorescence = less degraded varnish (or thick layer, more fluorophore volume). Dim/orange-brown fluorescence = heavily degraded (oxidation, cross-linking advanced; emission shifts red, intensity decreases; or thin residual layer after partial cleaning). **Distribution:** Even fluorescence = even varnish (original application, or uniform restoration varnishing). Patchy = selective cleaning (past campaigns removed varnish in some regions: faces, foreground cleaned, background left; common 19th-century practice), or uneven application (restorer brushed thicker in center, thinner edges). **Quantify:** Measure intensity variations (ROI analysis: 5 areas across painting, mean fluorescence 160, 175, 155, 140, 180 → ±10% variation, reasonably even; vs. 200, 80, 190, 75, 195 → 2-3× variation, very patchy, indicates selective cleaning or degradation). **Treatment decision:** If varnish degraded (dark fluorescence, brown discoloration in normal photo): recommend removal, apply fresh varnish (modern synthetic Regalrez, MS2A; weak UVF initially, but over decades will develop fluorescence too). If varnish uneven: remove entirely (avoid patchwork appearance post-cleaning), or accept historical character (document, monitor).

steps.title: Integration with Other Imaging Modalities
steps.description: UVF complements other techniques: **UV + Visible + IRR + X-ray standard suite (paintings):** UVF detects retouching, varnish (surface materials, organic binders). IRR underdrawing, pentimenti (subsurface, carbon-based). X-ray dense pigments (Pb, Hg), support structure. Visible normal appearance, color. Combined: comprehensive (UV surface organics, visible color, IRR composition beneath, X-ray structure/pigments; each reveals different information, together complete picture). **UV + XRF (material ID):** UVF shows fluorescence (organic binders, varnish). XRF shows elements (Pb, Zn, Hg; inorganic pigments). Correlate: bright blue UVF + Zn XRF = zinc white (both confirm). Yellow-green UVF + no strong elemental signal XRF = organic (varnish, dye, lake pigment; XRF detects trace metals if mordant, but mainly organic). Overlay: XRF elemental map (colored by element) + UVF fluorescence (grayscale background) → spatial distribution elements + organic materials in single figure. **UV + Macro (#4):** Macro high-resolution texture (brushstrokes, cracks, grain structure, 5-50 μm/pixel). UVF material identification (fluorescence color). Combine: macro UVF (see technique #5 this document, detail imaging section) → fluorescence at microscale (individual pigment grains fluoresce? fiber-level textile fluorescence?). Example: macro UVF painting shows modern retouching brushstroke 200 μm wide (dark fluorescence, smooth texture) adjacent original 500 μm wide (bright fluorescence, crazed texture) → both morphology + fluorescence confirm distinction. **UV + Cross-Polarization (#3):** Cross-polarization removes glare (surface optical properties). UVF removes surface reflection by imaging fluorescence (different mechanism). Both reveal subsurface: XP subsurface color, scattering; UVF subsurface organic fluorophores. Sometimes concordant (modern retouching dark in both XP matte + UVF non-fluorescent), sometimes divergent (aged varnish glossy in normal photo, suppressed in XP, but fluoresces in UVF → XP shows texture without glare, UVF shows chemistry; use both, cross-validate).
